title: Multi-focus - difference in finch calls table

content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

The common house finch is a small songbird that begins to look for a mate in early winter. Buzz, an ecologist, plans to investigate the frequency of mating calls, measured by counting the number of mating calls per hour, for the finch during mating season.

Suppose the probability is <math alttext="0.22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that a finch in a certain area makes at least <math alttext="42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mating calls per hour. Buzz selected a random sample of <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> finches from the large population of finches in the area and recorded the number of mating calls per hour for each finch in the sample.
(a) In the context of Buzz’s sample, interpret the meaning of the value computed by <math alttext="open parenthesis, 1 minus 0.22, close parenthesis, to the 30 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.22</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

The common house finch is a small songbird that begins to look for a mate in early winter. Buzz, an ecologist, plans to investigate the frequency of mating calls, measured by counting the number of mating calls per hour, for the finch during mating season.

Suppose the probability is <math alttext="0.22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that a finch in a certain area makes at least <math alttext="42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mating calls per hour. Buzz selected a random sample of <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> finches from the large population of finches in the area and recorded the number of mating calls per hour for each finch in the sample.
(a) In the context of Buzz’s sample, interpret the meaning of the value computed by <math alttext="open parenthesis, 1 minus 0.22, close parenthesis, to the 30 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.22</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The computer output below provides the summary statistics of the number of mating calls per hour for each of the <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> finches in Buzz’s sample.

Min
 Max
 <math alttext="Q 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="Q 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Median
 Mean
 Standard Deviation

<math alttext="22" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="54" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>54</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="38" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>38</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="39" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>39</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Would it be unusual for a finch from Buzz’s sample to have made <math alttext="53" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>53</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mating calls per hour? Justify your answer.

(c) Consider the situation where the minimum value was incorrectly recorded as <math alttext="22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is actually <math alttext="32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe the effect that an increase from <math alttext="22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mating calls per hour to <math alttext="32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mating calls per hour would have on the median and interquartile range (<math alttext="I Q R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>Q</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) of Buzz’s sample. Explain your reasoning.

Buzz plans to use the sample data to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence that all common house finches in the area have a mean number of mating calls per hour that is not <math alttext="42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(d) State, in words, the hypotheses for the appropriate test.

Assume all conditions for inference are met. The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of Buzz’s test was approximately <math alttext="0.049" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.049</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(e) Interpret what the value <math alttext="0.049" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.049</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> measures in the context of the study.

Diane, another ecologist, selected a new random sample from the population of all common house finches in the area and also obtained a sample mean of <math alttext="39" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>39</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. She then conducted the same inference procedure as Buzz had in order to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence that all common house finches from the area have a mean number of mating calls per hour that is not <math alttext="42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of Diane’s test was approximately <math alttext="0.019" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.019</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(f) Identify one possible difference between Buzz’s and Diane’s samples that resulted in Diane’s test having a smaller <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value. Explain how this difference results in a smaller <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value for Diane’s test.

topic.text: 1.7: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
